technology: There were no technical difficulties during the conversation.
cur_neg_affect: The participant expresses some mild negative affect by acknowledging that COVID still exists, but overall seems to have a positive outlook.
past_neg_affect: The participant describes the initial cancellation of events and the shift to remote learning as negative experiences, but also highlights the positive aspects of spending time with family.
communal_orientation: The participant actively listens to the conversation partner, shares personal experiences, and expresses appreciation for the partner's insights, indicating a moderate level of communal orientation.
engagement: The participant is actively engaged in the conversation, sharing personal experiences, asking questions, and responding thoughtfully to the conversation partner's comments.
defensiveness: The participant does not exhibit any defensive behavior or statements during the conversation.

questions.transcript: What was your Covid experience like?
Did you end up getting the vaccine?
Do you think in the future you would try to get like a yearly covid vaccine? I guess.

similarity_statements.transcript: Yeah. So I remember when all about what was happening in China and Italy, and in my mind, I was like, Oh, it's not gonna like, come here like it won't be bad
And I was like, that's weird like, is it really that serious?
And I was like, Oh, my gosh! Like this is actually getting really serious.
And I was like, Oh, my gosh!
And I was like, this is literally the world we're living in.

But I was like thankful that I got to be at home and spend time with my family, which I never would have been able to otherwise, and and even though, like the next year of like online school was like not great it was
I was still thankful that I was like, well, thank goodness, we have technology.
You said like early February 2020 20. What a unique experience to have on the plane!
Very early on, I think. I remember watching like pandemic movies, too.
Like, I definitely watch contagion, and I think worldwide, which is more certainly zombie.
And I was like, Okay, great.
And and I was like, well, like, not really like. It's a little bit more complicated than that I mean, like, obviously, I I was looking forward to like their vaccine cause.
But I'm like, does anyone actually know how efficient it is?

So I was like a little nervous, like what I was getting it so I was like, oh, might be out all day tomorrow, cause, like everyone else I knew was really sick after getting it, but I was thankful that I had really no effect.
Yeah, I agree, yeah, I think, like my, my experience was always like, I got a little bit like the inside scoop from around, just cause like my, like, I said, my parents like work in the hospital.

vaccine_importance: The participant acknowledges the importance of vaccines in providing hope and a sense of control during the pandemic, but expresses skepticism about the rapid development process.
booster_importance: The participant indicates a reluctance to get more boosters, suggesting a belief that the pandemic is nearing its end and that COVID will become a manageable part of life, similar to the flu.
cognitive_complexity: The participant demonstrates cognitive complexity by acknowledging both the positive and negative aspects of the pandemic, considering the complexities of vaccine development, and recognizing the importance of hope in a crisis.
general_notes: The participant seems to have a generally positive outlook, focusing on the lessons learned and the importance of family during the pandemic. They are somewhat skeptical of the vaccine development process but ultimately chose to get vaccinated and boosted.
